section.para: September 1999 Requirements (Use Cases) Gathering for Common Repository (CRS)
August 2000 Designed auto-query capability based on HTML meta-information
October 2000 First director demonstration of front-end capabilities

December 2000 Re-architectured and re-implemented front-end to include work flow capability, use of reflection for query components, more robust handling of query components and output components, and re-designed HTML meta-information
January 2001 First public release of system as the CAASD Repository System (CRS)
April 2001 Added intelligent handling of join path. Added drill-down capability, lat-long box, and a few other new widgets
June 2001 Version 1 of the Form Builder implemented
August 2001 Logins and personalized forms added. Now tracking individual usage

September 2001 Form Builder refined enough to release to users, and users can share their forms with other users. Later in the month, the system plays an integral part in determining who within MITRE had access to ETMS flight data after the terrorist attack of 9/11/01

February 2002 Released DirectQuery for public use. This facility had been in use by the developers and many of the more knowledgeable users for quite some time. Also wrote a facility for uploading many queries at once (direct query upload)
April 2002 Added custom outputs to feed produce input files for analysis tools
June 2002 MITRE files a patent applied to United States Patent and Trademark Office for technology MRALD implements

July 2002 First really good, successful customization with new work flows. Added a work flow step to modify queries adding in clues for the query optimizer to use when querying large data sets. This resulted in a 50 to 99% decrease in query execution time. Also added personal query history, some enhanced widgets, and filter operators for NULLs in the database
November 2002 Neuroinformatics project starts to take over much of the drive and funding for furthering MRALD. CRS ceases to be the driving factor in pushing MRALD features and development.
May 2003 MRALD was formally extracted from the CRS codebase and started as a separate, pilot project in the MITRE Internal SourceForge (iSF) repository

listitem.para:
Enhancements
New, much more powerful form builder
Fixed the code so it parsed date formats much more flexibly
Added Count(*) capability
Added an IN filter so the user can provide a list of values or even a nested query
Form navigation on all html pages
A new type of OR filter that allows you to select multiple table.fields match a single value (e.g., Departure or Arrival airport is IAD)

Enhancements
Added ability to sort descending as well as ascending

Enhancements
Edit Form capability. Users can now edit their personal forms after they've been created using an almost identical interface to the one that created it
Formbuilder validation. There's a new work flow step to catch forms that are invalid. Feedback is given to the user building the form on why a form is invalid and how to fix it. A valid form has a single, acyclic join path between all tables on the form
New exception handling facility. Two new classes provide a consistent error handling philosophy taking into account the opportunities the MRALD architecture provides and the chained exception facility of Java 1.4. Over the next few releases, all MRALD classes will be retrofitted to take advantage of this facility. These new exception handling classes also provide more detailed output when a problem occurs, making diagnostics and debugging easier
Package level documentation in javadocs
Enhanced administration area. A few goodies for the Administrators
Added ability to log out
Added buffered, multi-leveled logger

Major Bug Fix
Formbuilder: Or Filters now pick up the operator correctly

section.para: February 2004 Commercial Intellectual Property rights for patent application sold to private IT company

listitem.para:
Major Bug Fixes
Fixed two instances where a connection to the database could be opened but never closed.

Enhancements
filler
Administrative Control. As an administrator, the user will be allowed to change many of the MRALD system properties
MRALD workflows can be edited. You can add or remove steps and add or remove entire workflows.
Any .props or .properties files in the properties directory can be edited. This includes any files you may have for local customizations of MRALD.
News can now be edited in the web browser
Improved Log Manipulation and Management. With the new error catching method, log files are created and easily managed through the administrative interface.
Passwords. MRALD now requires the use of passwords for users to log in. If you want to disable this, you'll have to recompile MRALD with the Config.usingSecurity property set to false. Note that existing deployments will have to add a "password" column to their people table; type is VARCHAR(50).
Improved Security Measures. The system was restructured to enable the web server to run under the JVM security manager. This allows SSL connections as well as strict restrictions on system access from the JVM. Users now must provide a password in order to login to the MRALD system. There also exists facilities to retrieve, change, and register passwords.
Passwords. MRALD now requires the use of passwords for users to log in. If you want to disable this, you'll have to recompile MRALD with the Config.usingSecurity property set to false.
Simplified Setup. The first time someone attempts to connect to a new MRALD instance (assumed to be the administrator who installed it), a setup page will allow the user to change the configuration properties. MRALD also will now create the critical People table in your database if it has not already been created.
API to add custom JDBC Connection strings. This is especially important for Oracle databases, which take all sorts of interesting properties.
Update/Delete Form Builder. These dynamically created forms follow the same process as the FormBuilder but give the capability to update or delete existing data in the database.
Insert Form Builder. Now you can create dynamic insertion forms that will allow the user to enter in data through a web form.
User Guide. We now have version 1 of the MRALD Users Guide ready. Two other manuals, one for deplores and one for developers, are planned.
Added checks to ensure the user puts in a structurally valid email address

Major Bug Fixes
Fixed two instances where a connection to the database could be opened but never closed.
Due to deficiencies found in load testing, changes were made to ensure MRALD is a highly scalable system that can operate under extreme loads with many concurrent users.
Fixed memory leak in OutputManager.
Fixed code for deployments on Windows and for compatibility with IE.
Fix so people table is automatically created properly on all databases. Non SQL-standard data types were used.

Enhancements
Extreme load testing and resulting changes ensure that MRALD is a highly scalable system that can operate under extreme loads with many concurrent users.
New look and simple forms. MRALD has a new look and feel throughout. In addition, data retrieval forms now come in two flavors - simple and advanced. The advanced forms are identical in functionality to the old forms. The simple forms retrieve a set number of data fields (those that are defaulted when building the form), there are no statistical functions, and output is html only. All explicitly built filters are inlcuded, but none of the generic ones are.
New keyword search features a search throughout the entire database for a single word or phrase. The search is case sensitive and checkes only the text fields in the database. The result is a list of all tables where the word appears and all the rows in the table that contain the word.
New Drill down output type. This output type will provide links for all primary or foreign keys in your query. Following these links will take the user to all data linked directly off that table. Works only from MRALD forms - doesn't work off DirectQuery.
Database schema browser added.
New license. Added licenseing information for MRALD and all included components.
Added documentation for the form of common JDBC connection strings to help in initial setup. Notes and links were added to initial setup pages as well as when editing config.properties from the interface.
Split out the config.properties into two files. config.properties contains all the things that are normally changed; standard.properties contains properties that should only be changed if you really know what you are doing. It is optional, so if you keep all your settings in config.properties, it's OK.
Incorporated the User's Guide into the standard build.
Query history now does a better job parsing multi-line queries and properly feeds them in to the query text box in DirectQuery
Added an option to all output types to display the query with the output.
Multiple fixes for changes in Java 5.
Apostrophes (') are now handled in the code.
Added transition page during query execution.
Added NOT IN operator.
Added basic charting capability - only bar charts are currently supported.
New filter type - Categorical filters. A categorical filter is one where the values are from a small, known set. This filter will grab the values from a database and present them to the user in the form of a drop down box.
Faster form building.

Other Code Changes
Regresses logging to old method. It was slow and file system intensive but the alternatives proved to be unacceptable and Tomcat 5 was taking over the logging.
Added a rudimentary messaging facility. Not completely implemented yet.
Restructured code to allow for an mrald-util.jar file. It contains the control and util packages.
The code no longer uses the peopleid field. The primary key for the people table is the email field.
Added site title as a config property - now you don't have to change every jsp to change the title of the installation.
Updated member access levels in many files to prevent un-intended side effects and direct manipulation of variables that shouldn't be modified.
During installation, an admin@mitre.org user is provided to bootstrap the system.
